title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [6–27 april? 1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [6–27 April? 1867]
text: Brooklyn 27 April 1867saturdaySaturday 2 oclocko'clockmy dear Walti have just receevedreceived your letter with 1 dollar in it the rain perhaps deterddeterred my getting it earlyerearlier but i was glad to get it any how glad to hear from you that you are having time to take some recreations and very glad to have the dollar you will say a dollar aintain't much but sometimes it is worth more than 2 or 3 at another time george has had more than usual to pay this month in sessmentsassessments and insurance but i have had quite considerable from him so i wanted a letter to day and it come from the good old stand by) Jeffy worried quite much because he couldentcouldn't leave me something in the way of a present but he said he had to pay so much more away than he expected that he was rather short but he would send me some when he got back i told him i got along very well to not worry about that he went away tuesdayTuesday night he is not going straitstraight home but will arrive home if nothing happens on mondayMonday night we had company almost all of last week which made me more short of funds but i didentdidn't want for anything) george has got the galaxyGalaxy just come with it walt i suppose you see that little peicepiece in the thursdayThursday times about your being the only american poet i cut it out and was going to send it to jeff if you haventhaven't seen it i will send it to you georgey is quit pumping on the water works mr Lane puts great confidence in him the new manemain that was laid last fall leaks in many places george had to go the other night to see about it mr lane came here very much alarmed it spouts out almost liklike a fountain so yesterday they stopped it george was mud from head to foot) walter dear give my love to mr and mrs OconerO'Connor likewise the boroughsBurroughs and take the rest for yourselfgood bieaintain't the galaxy large and reelreal nice Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [6–27 April? 1867]
